factoid: The officer knew no one.
The officer wore a smart Guardsman's uniform.
The officer was an insignificant officer of the Guards.
Exalted personages passing in the streets in elegant carriages with plumes, ribbons, and medals seemed immeasurably above the officer.
The exalted personages were courtiers and military men.
The exalted personages did not wish to be aware of the officer's existence.
The exalted personages could not be aware of the officer's existence.
The officer inquired for Bolkónski at the quarters of Commander in Chief Kutúzov.
All adjutants and orderlies looked at the officer as if they wished to impress that many officers like the officer were always coming there.
All adjutants and orderlies looked at the officer as if they wished to impress that everybody was heartily sick of the officers.
The officer again went to Olmütz on November 15 after dinner.
The officer entered the house occupied by Commander in Chief Kutúzov.
The officer asked for Bolkónski.
Prince Andrew was in the house.
Borís was shown into a large hall.
The large hall was probably formerly used for dancing.
The large hall contained five beds.
The large hall contained a table.
The large hall contained chairs.
The large hall contained a clavichord.
The adjutant nearest the door was sitting at the table in a Persian dressing gown and writing.
Nesvítski was red and stout, lay on a bed with arms under his head, and laughed with an officer who had sat down beside him.
The third adjutant was playing a Viennese waltz on the clavichord.
The fourth adjutant was lying on the clavichord and sang the tune.
Bolkónski was not present.
None of the gentlemen changed position when they saw Borís.
The adjutant who was writing turned round crossly and told Borís that Bolkónski was on duty.
The adjutant told Borís to go through the door on the left into the reception room if he wished to see Bolkónski.
Borís thanked the adjutant.
Borís went to the reception room.
In the reception room Borís found about ten officers and generals.
Prince Andrew had eyes drooping contemptuously.
Prince Andrew was listening to an old Russian general with decorations.
The old Russian general stood very erect, almost on tiptoe.
The old Russian general had a soldier's obsequious expression on his purple face.
The old Russian general was reporting something.
Prince Andrew said to the general, "Very well, then, be so good as to wait."
Prince Andrew spoke in Russian.
Prince Andrew spoke with French intonation when he wished to speak contemptuously.
Prince Andrew noticed Borís.
Prince Andrew paid no more heed to the general who ran after him imploring him to hear something more.
Prince Andrew nodded and turned to the general with a cheerful smile.
Borís realized that in the army, besides the subordination and discipline prescribed in the military code, there was another, more important subordination.
The other subordination made the tight-laced, purple-faced general wait respectfully.
Captain Prince Andrew chose to chat with Lieutenant Drubetskóy for his own pleasure.
Borís resolved to serve in future not according to the written code but under the unwritten law.
Borís felt that by being recommended to Prince Andrew he had risen above the general who had the power to annihilate him.
The general was a lieutenant of the Guards.
Prince Andrew came up to Borís and took his hand.
Prince Andrew said he was very sorry that Borís did not find him yesterday.
Prince Andrew said he was fussing about with Germans all day.
Prince Andrew said they went with Weyrother to survey the dispositions.
Prince Andrew said when Germans start being accurate, there’s no end to it.
Borís smiled as if he understood what Prince Andrew was alluding to as something generally known.
This was the first time Borís had heard Weyrother’s name.
This was the first time Borís had heard the term "dispositions."
Prince Andrew said "Well, my dear fellow, so you still want to be an adjutant?"
Prince Andrew said "I have been thinking about you."
Borís said he was thinking of asking the commander in chief.
Borís said the commander in chief had a letter from Prince Kurágin about him.
Borís said he only wanted to ask because he feared the Guards wouldn’t be in action.
Prince Andrew replied "All right, all right. We’ll talk it over."
Prince Andrew said "Only let me report this gentleman’s business, and I shall be at your disposal."
